questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) from diabetic nephropathy has been on hemodialysis for three years. She reports persistent back pain and changes in posture. An X-ray shows specific findings, shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyperparathyroidism

 

Explanation:

The scenario depicts a case of Renal osteodystrophy (Secondary Hyperparathyroidism), with the X-ray showing Rugger jersey spine.

 

Radiological features of Hyperparathyroidism
  • Subperiosteal resorption usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side, leading to a concavity of bone (the earliest bone change). 

 
  • The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull). 

 
  • Brown tumor or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions resulting from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can cause bone expansion, often accompanied by hemorrhage and granulation tissue (more common in primary hyperparathyroidism).



 
  • Rugger jersey spine: Characterized by alternating black and white striations, with sclerosed white end plates and black vertebral bodies; commonly seen in renal osteodystrophy (secondary hyperparathyroidism). 

 

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option A) shows sacroiliac joint erosions, bamboo spine and dagger sign.

 



 

Osteoporosis (Option C)  show osteopenia and biconcave vertebrae, often referred to as codfish or fish-mouth vertebrae. 


 

Osteoblastic metastases (Option D)  is characterised by increased density and sclerosis, commonly referred to as "ivory vertebra."

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of heart failure and sensorineural hearing loss presents with worsening bone pain in his pelvis and lower back, fatigue, heaviness in his legs, tibial deformities, and occasional headaches. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels. Which radiographic finding is least likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Champagne glass pelvis.

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario describes a case of Paget’s disease (osteitis deformans).
  • The champagne glass pelvis (Option D)  is typically observed in Achondroplasia and is not associated with Paget's disease. 


 

Paget’s disease (osteitis deformans):

  • A non-neoplastic condition that is characterised by abnormal bone remodelling.
  • Clinical features:
    • Seen in elderly patients
    • Presents with bone pain, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) (cranial nerve compression)
    • Cardiac failure (hyperdynamic circulation)
    • Raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP), but calcium and phosphorous levels are normal
  • Radiological features:

Osteoporosis circumscripta (Option A) : A circumscribed patch of osteoporosis in the skull.


 

The cotton wool appearance of the skull (due to sclerosis)

Tam O'Shanter sign: The skull's expansion and flattened base create the appearance of the skull tilting over the facial structures (due to the thickening of the frontal bone).

(Option B)

Blade of grass appearance or candle flame sign (Option C): Flame-shaped lesion extending along the shaft of the bone.

Picture frame vertebra:

The vertebrae appear enlarged and have a thickened cortical bone due to excessive bone remodeling and disorganized osteoblastic activity.

Ivory vertebra:

 

Lincoln sign or Black Beard sign: Increased radiotracer uptake in the mandible gives it a distinctive black beard appearance that signifies abnormal bone metabolism in Paget’s disease.

Banana fractures: Occur in a region of abnormal bone.

questions.text:
Match the following skull findings according to their respective conditions.


	
		
			
			S.No
			
			
			Finding
			
			
			Condition
			
		
		
			
			1.
			
			
			
			a) Paget’s Disease
			
		
		
			
			2.
			
			
			
			b) Hyperparathyroidism
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			
			c) Sickle Cell Anemia
			
		
		
			
			4.
			
			
			
			d) Multiple Myeloma
			
		
		
			
			5.
			
			
			
			e) Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e, 5-c

 

Explanation:

Radiological findings of the skull in different conditions

Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Salt and pepper appearance of the skull is due to lytic lesions caused by calcium resorption.

Multiple Myeloma:

  • Well-defined Punched-out lesions involving both the tables of the skull.

Paget’s Disease:

  • Cortical Expansion
  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: Focal areas of osteolytic lesions
  • Tam’o Shanter Sign: Thickening of Frontal Bone.
  • Cotton Wool Appearance of the Skull is also seen.

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis:

  • Bevelled Lytic Lesion: Well-defined lytic lesion with sclerotic margin.

Sickle Cell Anemia:

  • Crew cut Appearance: Due to Extramedullary Hematopoiesis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with short stature and disproportionate limb length. His parents mention he has a broad forehead and has been slower to walk than peers & genetic testing reveals mutation in FGFR3 gene. Based on this presentation, which of the following radiological findings is least likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tam o'shanter sign

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation along with FGFR3 gene mutation suggests Achondroplasia & tam o'shanter sign is not typically associated with this condition. It is associated with Paget’s disease.

 

Achondroplasia

  • Genetic condition caused by FGFR3 gene mutation featuring short stature and short proximal limbs, kyphosis, exaggerated lumbar lordosis
  • Radiological findings:
    • Trident hand sign (Option C)
    •  

 

  • Pelvic champagne glass appearance (Option D)

 

  • Tombstone appearance of the iliac blade

 

  • Bullet nose vertebrae (Option A)

 

  • Chevron sign

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency department with sudden pain in her right foot after playing soccer. She reports hearing a "snap" when she landed awkwardly while attempting to head the ball. On examination, swelling and tenderness are noted. An X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Jones fracture

 

Explanation:

The presented scenario, along with the X-ray findings, is diagnosed as a Jones fracture.

 

Jones fracture

Site

Fracture of the base of the fifth metatarsal (extra-articular fracture)

Mechanism

It is caused by the pull exerted by the tendon of the peroneus brevis muscle inserted on it.

X-ray

Pseudo- jones Fracture (Option C):

  • Intra-articular fracture at the base of 5th metatarsal.


 

Aviator fracture (Option A) is the fracture of the neck of the talus resulting from forced dorsiflexion of the ankle.

Lover’s fracture (Option D) is a burst fracture of the calcaneus (heel bone). It typically occurs when the heel is crushed under body weight, such as in a car accident or a fall from a height.

questions.text:
Match the following fractures with their radiographs:

 


	
		
			
			1. Bennett’s fracture
			
			
			a.

			
			
		
		
			
			2. Rolando’s fracture
			
			
			b.

			
			
		
		
			
			3. Gamekeeper fracture
			
			
			c.

			
			
		
		
			
			4. Boxer’s fracture
			
			
			d.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

Fracture

Description

X-ray

Bennett’s fracture
  • Oblique intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the metacarpal.

Rolando’s fracture
  • A complete articular fracture (‘T' or 'Y' shaped) of the first metacarpal.

Skier’s thumb or Gamekeeper’s thumb

  • A tear of the ulnar collateral ligament in the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Boxer’s fracture

  • Fracture through the neck of the metacarpal (commonly the 5th metacarpal).
  • Cause: Closed fist hits against a hard object

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with wrist pain and swelling following a fall while skiing and also reports difficulty moving his wrist. Based on the X-ray findings, what is the cause of his condition?

choices.text: Radial styloid fracture leading to carpal instability

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Scapholunate ligament tear

 

Explanation: 

  • The above radiograph shows Terry Thomas sign, i.e increased gap between the scaphoid and lunate bones which is indicative of Scapholunate ligament dissociation.
  • This ligament tear commonly occurs after a fall onto an outstretched hand or may occur secondarily following a radial styloid fracture or a scaphoid fracture.

 

Category

Scapholunate dislocation

Scaphoid fracture

Definition

This occurs when an injury disrupts the scapholunate ligament, leading to instability between the scaphoid and lunate bones.

It can occur in 3 sites.

• Distal tubercle

• Waist (Common)

• Proximal pole

Mechanism of injury

• Fall on the dorsiﬂexed hand

• Fall on outstretched hand 

• Secondary to radial-styloid fracture

 

Signs & Radiological findings

Terry Thomas sign (increased gap between the scaphoid and lunate bones)

 

• Tenderness over anatomical snuff box.

• A ‘Humpback sign’ is observed in displaced fractures.

 

Waistline fracture of scaphoid (Option B)

Treatment

• Early detection: Surgical repair with K-wire fixation is done

• Chronic case (without arthritis):  Ligament repair is preferred.

• Chronic case (with arthritis): Proximal row carpectomy, four-corner fusion or radio scapholunate arthrodesis is preferred.

• Immobilization with Scaphoid cast or Bohler-Gauntlet scaphoid cast for undisplaced fractures

• ORIF with Herbert's screw.

Complications

• Carpal instability

• Increased risk of osteoarthritis.

• Avascular necrosis (Option A) is common in proximal pole fractures of the scaphoid due to the radial artery primarily supplying the distal pole.

 It may show a ground-glass appearance, increased bone density, and, occasionally, collapse and fragmentation on X-ray.

• Non-union

Radial styloid fracture, also known as a Chauffeur's fracture (Option C), is an intra-articular injury to the distal radius. The force responsible for this fracture may also cause a scaphoid fracture and damage to carpal ligaments, potentially leading to carpal instability.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with wrist pain and swelling after sustaining a fall on an outstretched hand. An X-ray is performed; what is the likely diagnosis based on the findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Barton’s fracture

 

Explanation:

  • The given X-ray depicts an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius, called Barton’s fracture.
  • It is usually accompanied by a dislocation of the radiocarpal joint.

 

Barton’s fracture

Site

Distal radius

Mechanism of injury

Fall on an outstretched hand

Displacement
  • Volar Barton’s fracture: Anterior displacement of the fracture fragment.
  • Dorsal Barton’s fracture: Posterior displacement of the fracture fragment. 

Management
  • Closed reduction
  • Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF)

X-ray

 

Hutchinson fracture (Option A), also called Chauffeur's fracture, is an intra-articular fracture of the radial styloid process at the distal radius caused by a fall or by direct impact in a car accident and commonly associated with carpal ligament injury.


 

Colles fracture (Option B) is an extra-articular distal radius fracture characterised by dorsal angulation and displacement, caused by a fall on an outstretched hand and commonly present with Dinner-fork deformity.

 

 

Smith fracture (Option C), also called Reverse-Colles fracture, involves a fracture of the distal radius with ventral displacement of the distal fragment. This fracture commonly occurs from a fall onto a flexed wrist, leading to a garden-spade deformity, along with wrist pain, swelling, and limited range of motion.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with severe neck pain and limited head movement after falling from a 13-foot building. Examination reveals tenderness and restricted motion in the cervical spine. Based on his radiological findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Jefferson fracture

 

Explanation:

  • The depicted radiograph is a CT scan of the cervical spine showing a Jefferson burst fracture of the C1 vertebra (atlas).
  • This fracture typically results from an axial load, such as a fall onto the head or a direct blow, causing a burst-type injury.
  • Features:
    • Lateral displacement of the lateral masses of C1 relative to C2.
    • Fracture lines in the anterior and posterior arches of C1.
    • Potential instability if there is transverse ligament rupture.
    • Unstable fractures: Posterior fixation with pedicle screw system 



 

Chance fracture (Option A) is a seatbelt injury that results from a flexion-distraction mechanism. It involves disruption of the posterior column structures and is frequently associated with intra-abdominal injuries. Radiographic findings show a horizontal fracture through the posterior elements or disruption of the facet joints and spinous processes. 



 

Hangman's fracture (Option B) refers to a bilateral fracture of the pedicles of the C2 vertebra caused by hyperextension and axial loading of the cervical spine. The lamina, pedicles, and other parts of the posterior axis may also be involved in this type of fracture.

 

Clay shoveller’s fracture (Option C) is an avulsion fracture of the spinous process in the lower cervical or upper thoracic spine. It typically occurs due to sudden muscle contraction or direct trauma to the upper back.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of persistent pain and swelling above the left ankle, with constant and worsening discomfort, especially during physical activity. On examination, there is tenderness and a palpable mass over the lateral aspect of the distal fibula. An X-ray shows characteristic findings depicted in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Osteosarcoma

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and X-ray findings show increased density in the distal fibula due to tumour-induced bone production, along blood vessels creates a radiographic appearance resembling sun rays, which strongly suggests Osteosarcoma.
  • It is the second most common and highly malignant primary bone tumor of mesenchymal cells.
  • It commonly occurs in the metaphysis of the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the upper end of the humerus.
  • Radiological Findings:
    • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis, often with new bone formation.
    • Periosteal reaction: Irregular, intense periosteal reaction distinct from the smooth, layered reaction seen in osteomyelitis.
    • Codman's Triangle: A triangular area of subperiosteal new bone at the tumour-host cortex junction. 

    • Sun-Ray Appearance: New bone formation along blood vessels creates a radiographic appearance resembling sun rays.



 

Ewing's Sarcoma (Option A) is an aggressive tumor that primarily affects children and presents as a diaphyseal lesion with an "onion peel" appearance on imaging. 



 

Osteoblastoma (Option C) is a benign tumor typically occurring in the jaw and spine, and in long bones, it is found in the diaphysis or metaphysis. Radiologically, it appears as a well-defined, expansile radiolucent bone lesion and won’t show a cortical reaction and aggressive features as in osteosarcoma.

 

Osteochondroma (Option D) typically manifests as an exophytic growth from the bone surface.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with localized pain and swelling in the anterior tibia. X-ray findings reveal the characteristics shown in the image. Based on these imaging features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Adamantinoma

 

Explanation: The given clinical scenario, along with the X-ray finding showing lobulated lucent cystic lesions with disruption of the anterior cortex in the tibia, points towards Adamantinoma.

 

Adamantinoma: (Rare, low-grade malignant tumor)

  • It primarily affects the tibial diaphysis in up to 90% of cases.
  • Commonly occurs in individuals aged 20 to 40 years
  • Typically present with pre-tibial pain, swelling, and occasionally fractures.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Expansive, lobulated lucent cystic lesion with disruption of the anterior cortex.
    • Lytic Lesions: Characterized by multiple well-defined lucencies (Honeycomb-like Appearance).
    • Sclerosis: Interspersed sclerotic areas within the lytic regions.
      • Extra-osseous Extension: 30% of cases 


 

Most Common Sites of Primary Bone Tumor:

Epiphysis

Metaphysis

Diaphysis
  • Chondroblastoma: Most common before puberty.
  • Osteoclastoma/GCT(Giant Cell Tumor): Most common after puberty.
  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Osteochondroma
  • Bone Cyst
  • Enchondroma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Osteoclastoma
  • Ewing’s Tumor
  • Lymphoma
  • Multiple Myeloma
  • Adamantinoma
  • Osteoid Osteoma
        


 

Giant Cell Tumor (Osteoclastoma) (Option B) typically occurs in the epiphyseal region of long bones, especially around the knee, after puberty. It is characterized by a distinct "soap-bubble appearance" on imaging due to multiloculated lytic lesions.

 

Simple Bone Cyst (Option A) typically appears as a well-defined, unilocular lytic lesion with a thin, sclerotic border in the metaphysis of long bones. It does not disrupt the cortex or cause significant soft tissue mass.

 

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (Option C) appears as an expansile, lytic lesion with a "multilocular" appearance. It typically affects the metaphysis and may cause cortical thinning or disruption. MRI often shows a blood-filled cystic structure with fluid levels.

questions.text: A 10-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggestive of osteomyelitis. An MRI is performed, and the radiologist notes a finding indicative of acute osteomyelitis. Which of the following findings is considered pathognomonic for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bone marrow edema

Explanation:

  • The pathognomonic MRI finding of acute osteomyelitis is bone marrow edema, which appears as high signal intensity on T2-weighted images and low signal intensity on T1-weighted images & is one of the earliest radiological signs and appears within 24 hours (Earliest- Bone scintigraphy)
  • The penumbra sign (Option A) (Ring enhancement due to granulation tissue) is pathognomonic for subacute osteomyelitis, especially in cases of Brodie's abscess.
  • Sequestrum (Option C) refers to a piece of dead bone that has separated from healthy bone, commonly seen in chronic osteomyelitis.
  • Involucrum (Option D) is the new bone formation that develops around the sequestrum, indicative of chronic osteomyelitis. 



 

Characteristic Radiological Features of Osteomyelitis:

Imaging Modality

Acute Osteomyelitis

Subacute Osteomyelitis

Chronic Osteomyelitis

Plain Radiograph
  • Minimal findings
  • Possible soft-tissue swelling

(5-7 days to appear)
  • Lucent/sclerotic lesions
  • Periosteal reaction
  • Soft-tissue swelling
  • Bone sclerosis
  • Cortical thickening
  • Sequestrum
  • Cloaca
  • Bone destruction

Computed Tomography

Not Useful
  • Cortical/marrow abnormalities
  • Abscess
  • Periosteal reaction
  • Edema

Superior to radiograph

for showing:

  • Cloaca/sequestrum
  • Periosteal new bone formation
  • Abscess

MRI

Early bone

marrow edema

(low T1, high T2)
  • Bone marrow/cortical changes
  • Increased T2 in soft tissues
  • Abscess formation;
  • Post-gadolinium T1 outlines the abscess cavity clearly
  • Enhanced resolution for Sequestra & Cloaca
  • Outline abscess/sinus tracts

Bone scintigraphy

Increased uptake

 

Diabetic Foot Osteomyelitis: T1-weighted images show low signal intensity in the marrow near an ulcer or sinus tract as the main indicator of osteomyelitis.

 

Brodie’s Abscess: Common in children and presents as a centrally located lesion aligned vertically along the bone's axis, characterized by a sclerotic margin.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with mild left arm pain, which has worsened over the past few months, particularly after a recent fall while playing. There are no signs of infection or soft tissue involvement. An X-ray shows the findings depicted in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Simple Bone Cyst

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of left arm pain and swelling, along with an X-ray showing a well-defined, unilocular lytic lesion in the metaphysis of the left humerus, without infection or soft tissue involvement, suggests a diagnosis of a simple bone cyst.

Fallen fragment sign: 

 

Features

Simple Bone Cyst (SBC)

(Option A)

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC)

(Option B ruled out)

Nature

Solitary, unilocular

Benign, expansile, multi-cystic

Fluid Content

Serous or sero-sanguinous

Blood-filled

Age Group

Children and adolescents

Children and teenagers

Locations

Proximal humerus, femur, tibia

Metaphysis of long bones, spine

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic; pathological fracture

Pain and swelling; possible neurological symptoms

Imaging

Well-defined, lytic lesions

Poorly defined, eroding lesions

X-ray

  

 

Brodie Abscess (Option C) involves a chronic bone abscess where the body has contained an infection, resulting in pus or jelly-like granulation tissue, surrounded by a sclerotic zone & has associated features of infection.

 

Sequestrum (Option D) is a piece of dead bone separated from living bone, often due to infection or chronic inflammation. On X-ray, it appears as a dense, irregularly shaped area within the bone, often surrounded by a zone of lucency. In cases of chronic osteomyelitis, an involucrum may form, which is new bone growth that encases the sequestrum.

.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with pain in the thigh and a noticeable deformity, as shown in the image. This deformity can be seen in all the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osteopetrosis

 

Explanation:

  • The deformity described is the shepherd's crook deformity of the femur, characterized by a bowing of the proximal femur.
  • It results in a reduction of the femoral neck angle to nearly 90°, leading to a coxa vara deformity.
  • This is commonly seen in conditions like Paget's disease of bone, osteogenesis imperfecta, and fibrous dysplasia. However, osteopetrosis (Option C), a condition marked by excessive bone density, is not typically associated with this deformity.

 



 

  • Osteopetrosis is a condition characterized by excessive bone density and is typically associated with Erlenmeyer flask deformity, also known as metaphyseal flaring.

 

Paget's disease of bone (Option A): This condition involves abnormal bone remodeling that can lead to softened, enlarged bones prone to bowing and the characteristic "shepherd's crook" deformity, especially in the femur.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option B): Due to defective collagen, bones are brittle and prone to recurrent fractures and progressive bowing deformities, including the "shepherd's crook" shape, from normal weight-bearing.

Fibrous dysplasia (Option D): Replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue, particularly in the proximal femur, results in weakened areas that can progressively bow into the distinct "shepherd's crook" deformity under mechanical stress.

questions.text: Which angle is typically used to measure the degree of spinal curvature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cobb angle

 

Explanation:

The given X-ray finding suggests Scoliosis and Cobb Angle is used to assess the degree of curvature in this condition.

 

Cobb Angle:

  • It is measured by the intersection of perpendicular lines drawn to the end plates of the most tilted vertebrae in a spinal curve.
  • A Cobb angle greater than 10° in the coronal plane indicates scoliosis. 


 

Codman Angle (Option A) is formed by the intersection of a line along the bone cortex and another line at the point where the periosteum is elevated. This is typically seen in conditions such as Ewing sarcoma and osteosarcoma. 

 

 

Ferguson Angle (Option C) is the angle formed between the plane of the sacral base (the upper surface of the sacrum) and the horizontal plane, used to assess lumbar lordosis.

Q Angle (Option D) is formed by the intersection of a line drawn from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the centre of the patella and a second line from the centre of the patella to the tibial tuberosity. 

The Q-angle assesses knee alignment and is used to evaluate patellofemoral dysfunction and ACL injury risk.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with persistent nocturnal pain in his right femur that is relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). On examination, there is localised tenderness in the area & no history of trauma. The radiographic evaluation shows a small, well-defined lytic lesion with a central nidus. What is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) CT scan of the femur

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and radiographic findings suggest Osteoid osteoma, characterized by nocturnal pain that is relieved by NSAIDs.
  • This benign bone tumor commonly affects young adults and is often located in the cortex of long bones, particularly the femur and tibia.
  • Characterized by a nidus that secretes prostaglandins, leading to intense nocturnal pain.
  • A CT scan is the investigation of choice (Osteoid osteoma is a cortical tumor. Hence, CT is superior to MRI which evaluates bone marrow & extent of tumors), revealing a central radiolucent nidus accompanied by surrounding sclerosis and a Vascular groove sign (thin channel in the thickened bone around the nidus)
  • It is managed by radiofrequency ablation.

 

 

X-ray (Option A) is used to diagnose fractures, joint conditions, tumours, and chest issues, as well as in dental assessments. It also guides treatment. Though an X-ray is the initial test for osteoid osteoma, CT provides better visualisation and confirms the diagnosis.

 

MRI (Option B) is used to diagnose soft tissue pathologies, bone marrow conditions, and neurological disorders, but it is not preferred for osteoid osteoma as it can obscure the nidus.

 

DEXA scan (Option C) measures bone mineral density to diagnose osteoporosis and assess fracture risk but is not preferred for osteoid osteoma as it does not provide detailed visualization of the lesion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of bilateral wrist and knee pain, worse with inactivity and improving with movement. She reports morning stiffness lasting over an hour, fatigue, and low-grade fever. On examination, hand deformities are noted. All of the following are associated with her condition except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Calcinosis cutis

 

Explanation:

  • The likely diagnosis is Rheumatoid arthritis (RA), a chronic inflammatory disease that typically presents with symmetrical joint involvement, prolonged morning stiffness, and systemic symptoms such as fatigue and low-grade fever.
  • Symmetrical involvement of small joints, including the wrists, elbows, knees, ankles, metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, with sparing of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints.
  • RA commonly leads to characteristic hand deformities such as
    • Boutonniere deformity (Option B) (flexion of the PIP joint and hyperextension of the DIP joint)
    • Swan neck deformity (Option C) (hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint)
    • Hitchhiker's thumb (or Z-deformity) (Option A), involving a hyperextension of the thumb's first joint.
  • Calcinosis cutis is the abnormal deposition of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissues, narrowing the joint spaces. It commonly occurs in CREST syndrome and is not related to Rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Signs & radiological findings of Rheumatoid arthritis
  • MCP joint’s subluxation  
 
  • Ball catcher's or Norgaard's view is used to evaluate the distal phalanx erosions.
 
  • Hammer toe (due to extended DIP and flexed PIP of the toe)  

 

 
  • Hitchhiker's thumb (caused by extended IP and flexed MCP of thumb)
 
  • Ulnar deviation of MCP
  • Swan neck deformity (caused by extended DIP and flexed PIP)
  • Boutonniere deformity (due to flexed PIP and extended DIP

questions.text:
Match the following X-rays with their corresponding diagnoses


	
		
			
			X-rays
			
			
			Diagnosis
			
		
		
			
			1.
			
			
			A. Achondroplasia
			
		
		
			
			2.
			
			
			B. Tuberculosis
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			C. Acromegaly
			
		
		
			
			4.
			
			
			D. Crest Syndrome
			
		
		
			
			5.
			
			
			E. Psoriatic Arthritis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-C, 2-A, 3-E, 4-B, 5-D

 

Explanation:

Spade phalanx

Acromegaly/ Gigantism

  • X-ray findings include
    • The distal phalanx is spade-shaped
    • Increased heel pad thickness
    • Wide joint spaces.
 

Trident Hand sign

Achondroplasia

  • X-ray findings:
    • Trident hand sign
    • Pelvic champagne glass appearance
    • Tombstone appearance of the iliac blade
    • Bullet nose vertebrae
    • Chevron sign 

 
 

Arthritis Mutilans

Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Extensive osteolysis of the Interphalangeal joints causing Arthritis Mutilans or opera glass hand deformity and pencil-in cup deformity
  • Telescoping fingers and sausage digits can be seen.
 

TB dactylitis

Tuberculosis of Phalanx

  • It shows Spina Ventosa or TB dactylitis, caused by the destruction of bone by a cyst-like cavity.
 

Calcinosis Cutis

CREST Syndrome

  • It is caused by the abnormal deposition of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissues.
  • Common in Scleroderma (Autoimmune condition)

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with chronic joint pain, stiffness, and mottling of teeth. He has a history of living in a rural area for several decades. His X-ray reveals increased bone density and calcification of ligaments. Based on these findings, which condition is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased fluoride intake

 

Explanation:

  • The radiograph above shows bone fluorosis, which results from excessive fluoride intake.
  • It results in back and joint pain and can lead to numbness and paresthesia of the lower limb due to spinal cord compression and anaemia.
  • Early finding of this condition is mottling of the teeth enamel (Dental Fluorosis)

 



 

  • X-ray findings are prevalent mostly in the vertebrae, forearm, leg and pelvis.

 

Fluorosis X-ray findings
  • Increased bone density
  • Cortical thickening
  • Osteosclerosis
  • Calcification of ligaments
  • Subperiosteal bone formation
  • Interosseous membrane calcification

 

Accumulation of Homogentisic acid (Option A) occurs in Ochronosis, a genetic condition caused by a deficiency of Homogentisic acid oxidase. Common radiological findings include intervertebral disc calcification, disc space narrowing, and osteoporosis.

 




 

Accumulation of Mucopolysaccharides (Option B) is seen in Mucopolysaccharidosis, resulting in dysostosis multiplex. X-ray findings include wedge-shaped vertebral bodies with anterior beaking, platyspondyly, dorsal kyphosis, wide disc spaces, and spinal canal stenosis.

 

Excessive accumulation of Iron (Option C) occurs in Hemochromatosis. Radiological findings include hooked osteophytes of the metacarpals, joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, and subchondral cyst formation.

questions.text: "Scotty dog" sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Normal vertebral findings

 

Explanation:

  • The given X-ray of the lumbar spine shows a fracture of the pars interarticularis, commonly associated with Spondylolysis.
  • This condition is characterised by the appearance of a "Scotty dog with a collar," which indicates a disruption of the Scotty dog appearance of normal lumbar vertebrae(Option A)

  • Spine degeneration from wear and tear can cause back pain and may affect nearby nerves, resulting in radiating pain, numbness, or paresthesia along the corresponding dermatomes.
  • This can lead to
    • Stress fracture of Pars Interarticularis of vertebrae
    • Spinal canal stenosis
    • Spondylolisthesis

 

 

Spondylolisthesis (Option B) occurs when a vertebra slips forward over the one below it, often leading to lower back pain and potential nerve compression. It is identified on an anterior-posterior (AP) X-ray by the inverted Napoleon hat sign in L5-S1 involvement and by the beheaded Scotty dog sign in a lateral view X-ray.

 

Osteoporosis (Option C) is characterised by reduced bone mass and density, which increases the risk of fractures. It presents with a "codfish" appearance due to increased vertebral concavity, decreased bone density, cortical bone thinning, reduced trabecular patterns, and potential vertebral compression fractures.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, notably taller than his peers, presents with lower back pain and has a history of frequent shoulder dislocations. Scoliosis is noted, and an MRI has been recommended for further evaluation. Which of the following conditions aligns with the given radiological finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Marfan syndrome

 

Explanation:

Scalloping of the vertebrae refers to the abnormal concave deformity observed on either the anterior or posterior aspect of the vertebral bodies.

 

 

Causes of Vertebral scalloping:

Posterior scalloping

Anterior scalloping

  • Neural Tumors and cysts
    • Schwannoma
    • Neurofibroma
    • Lipoma
    • Astrocytoma
  • Acromegaly
  • Achondroplasia
  • Loeys-Dietz syndrome
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Mucopolysaccharidosis
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy (Option B)
  • Abdominal aortic aneurysm (Option A)
  • Down syndrome (Option C)

questions.text: What is the most likely T-score that would confirm the diagnosis of osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) <-2.5

 

Explanation:

  • A Dual Energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan is primarily used to diagnose osteoporosis, assess fracture risk, and monitor drug therapy.
  • The DXA scanner uses X-rays with two energy peaks, enabling the differential absorption of radiation by bone and soft tissue, which facilitates the calculation of bone mineral density (BMD).
  • Interprets results using T-scores and Z-scores.
  • T-score: It compares a patient's BMD to the average BMD of a healthy young adult of the same sex. It indicates how much the patient's bone density deviates from the optimal peak bone mass.

WHO Criteria for Osteoporosis

T score

Interpretation

>-1.0 (Option A)

Normal BMD (bone mineral density)

-1.0 to -2.5 (Option B)

Osteopenia

<-2.5 (Option C)

Osteoporosis

<-2.5 with fracture (Option D)

Severe osteoporosis

 

  • Z-score: It compares the patient's BMD to the average BMD of individuals of the same age and sex. It helps assess whether the bone density is within a normal range for that specific demographic group.

Interpretation: A Z-score of -2.0 or lower may suggest significantly lower bone density compared to age-matched peers and may warrant further investigation into secondary causes of bone loss.

questions.text:
Match the following radiological findings with their associated condition.


	
		
			
			Radiological finding
			
			
			Condition
			
		
		
			
			1.
			
			
			 a) Paget's disease
			
		
		
			
			2.
			
			
			b) Vertebral hemangioma
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			c) Osteopetrosis
			
		
		
			
			4.
			
			
			d) Ankylosing spondylitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation:

Vertebral appearances

Seen in

Radiological image

Bone within bone appearance

Osteopetrosis

(Marble bone disease)

  • Bone within bone appearance

Intervertebral Disc Calcification
  • Ochronosis alkaptonuria
  • Ankylosing spondylitis

Polka Dot Appearance and Corduroy/Jail BarAppearance:

Vertebral hemangioma

Ivory Vertebrae
  • Paget's disease
  • Lymphoma
  • Osteoblastic metastasis

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with sickle cell anemia was diagnosed at birth. She recently went to the hospital due to severe back pain that worsens with activity, as well as numbness and tingling in her legs, difficulty walking, and occasional weakness in her lower extremities. Which option accurately represents the radiographic findings of her spine for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)

 

Explanation:

The radiographic findings in Sickle Cell Anemia reveal bone infarcts due ischemia of end arteries that result in H-shaped or Lincoln Log vertebrae.

 



 

Vertebral appearances and their associated diseases:

Vertebral appearances

Seen in

Radiological image

Rugger Jersey Spine

Renal osteodystrophy

(Secondary hyperparathyroidism)

Picture frame vertebra

(Option A)

Paget’s disease

H-shaped appearance or Lincoln Log Vertebrae

(Option C)

Sickle cell anemia

Biconcave Vertebrae (or) Codfish Vertebrae (or) Fish Mouth Vertebrae
  • Osteoporosis
  • Osteomalacia
  • Sickle cell anemia (later stages)

Vertebrae Plana

(Option D)
  • Trauma (most common cause in adults)
  • Eosinophilic granuloma (Langerhans cell histiocytosis)

Beaking of the Vertebrae
  • Mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS)
  • Hurler's syndrome (anterior beaking or bullet-shaped vertebrae) (Option B)
  • Hunter's syndrome
  • Morquio's syndrome (middle beaking)

Vertebral Scalloping
  • Posterior scalloping is seen in:
    • Dural ectasia (Marfan's syndrome or Neurofibromatosis)
    • Neurogenic tumors (e.g., schwannoma)
 
  • Anterior scalloping seen in:
    • Aortic aneurysm.
    • Lymphadenopathy of retroperitoneal and paraaortic lymph nodes (Tuberculosis)

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fatigue, swollen and bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and dry skin. After a dietary assessment, it is found that the child has been consuming a diet low in fruits and vegetables. Which radiographic feature is most indicative of the probable condition?

choices.text: Absence of white line of Frankel

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Wimberger’s Ring in the epiphysis

 

Explanation:

The scenario describes a case of Scurvy, which is characterised radiologically by the presence of Wimberger’s ring (ring epiphysis).

 

 

Scurvy

Rickets

Deficient vitamin

Vitamin C

Vitamin D

Reduced levels of

Collagen

Calcium
Clinical features
  • Increased capillary fragility
  • Appearance of petechiae on the skin
  • Delayed wound healing
  • Bleeding gums
  • Perifollicular hemorrhage
  • Frog-like posture (semiflexion at hips and knees): Due to the inability to move limbs due to pain (pseudoparalysis).
  • Scorbutic rosary (angular swellings at the costochondral junction arising due to subperiosteal bleed)
  • Genu varum (bow-legs) or Genu valgum (knock-knees)
 
  • Double-malleoli sign: The lateral malleolus of the ankles has two bony prominences instead of one.
  • Waddling gait
  • Frontal bossing
  • Delayed closure of anterior fontanelle
  • Craniotabes (soft skull bones with ping-pong ball consistency)
  • Delayed dentition and enamel hypoplasia.
  • Rachitic rosary (anterior chest wall has a beaded appearance due to swelling of costochondral cartilage junctions)
 
  • Harrison sulcus: Depression along the lower border of the chest at the site of insertion of the diaphragm.
  • Deformity of the hips: Coxa valga (femoral neck-shaft angle is increased) or coxa vara (femoral neck-shaft angle decreased)

Radiological features

  • Pencil-thin cortex
  • A white line of Frankel is present (dense zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis, giving a white line)
  • Trummerfeld’s zone or Scorbutic zone (black area adjacent to the white line of Frankel, due to lack of mineralisation of osteoid)
  • Wimberger's ring (epiphysis is small with a well-defined sclerotic margin, ring-shaped)
  • Pelkan's spur (extensions at the metaphysis)
  • Widening of the growth plate (Option A).
  • White Line of Frankel: Absent in active rickets (Option D); present in healing rickets after treatment.
  • Splaying (widening) of bones.
  • Cupping (concavity) (Option B) and fraying or (irregular margin) of bone ends.

  • Protrusio acetabuli and triradiate deformity of the pelvis.
